description:
The game of international drug interdiction by the U.S.

U.S. player attempts to prevent the Drug Czar player(s) from importing their contraband without turning America into a police state, while the Drug Czars attempt to get rich while avoiding arrest and their fellows.

America The New Game is a word game whose deck celebrates the United States of America, probably in conjunction with the 1933 Chicago World's Fair -- it being published in Chicago that year.

Its deck includes letters cards to cover the alphabet twice, in red and in black, and each letter has a different painting by the designer about an aspect of American history and heritage. About half the cards cover history, including Leif Ericsson, Columbus, the Mayflower, Declaration of Independence, first railroads, etc.  The rest of the cards cover the geographic range of America: the cities Washington D. C., Chicago and New York; the Statue of Liberty, steamboats, Niagara Falls, cotton plantations, wheat fields, orange groves, farms, cattle ranches, etc. It also includes an American Flag wild card, and a rules card. The cards are bridge size, measuring 88mm x 57mm.

It has rules for two games. "America" plays like Gin Rummy, with players drawing and discarding until someone goes out by playing a 7-letter word. At that point, everyone scores a word from their hand with bonus points for longer words, and for names of American cities or states. The largest point total is awarded if the 7-letter word is "America". "Alphabet Rhummy" plays like normal rummy, letting you play words to the table once you have them, as well as add letters to existing words to make new words. The first player out of cards gets one point per card in everyone else's hands.

One variety of the game has "America, Inc." on the cover, and another one does not.

Birdy can be played in two very different ways. Whether it involves matching colours and collecting birds or putting down bird cards on ones that have already been set out – both game variants promise loads of fun and develop children’s matching abilities.

Game 1: Feeding the birds 
 At the moment the birds can’t find anything to eat around them and need help from humans. Attract the  birds with food so that they don’t have to go hungry. The 25 bird cards are shuffled and then spread out on  the table face down. Three arbitrary cards are left face up so they are visible to all players, and the dice are 
placed nearby.
 The first player to roll a birdhouse starts. He then chooses one of the 3 face-up cards and tries to attract the selected bird by rolling the matching colours. The player has a total of 3 attempts, and can set aside any matching dice with each attempt – and continue to roll the dice/die the remaining times. The picture of a birdhouse functions as a joker and can stand for any colour. The X on the die is a „Lame Duck“, and can’t be placed anywhere. If the player manages to cover all colours after rolling the dice (a maximum of) three times, he can keep the card – otherwise, he has to put the card back. It is then the next player’s turn. If the previous player was able to collect a bird, then a new card is turned face up, so that there are 3 cards face up again. The object of the game is to attract 3 of the same kind of bird.
The game ends when one player has attracted 3 of the same birds. That player wins the round. If none of the players succeeds, the one who has collected the most birds wins.

Game 2: Bird dominoes

Can you link all of the birds onto the long chain of birds? Try to be the first player to attach all of your birds to the long row of birds. The 25 bird cards are shuffled thoroughly and spread out face down on the table – one card in the middle is turned face up, and one die is placed nearby. Then each player is given 4 bird cards to start with.

The first player to roll a birdhouse starts. The first player to roll a birdhouse starts. He rolls with one die, and there are the following possibilities:

     Rolls a colour: The colour that is rolled matches a “free colour point” on the card in the middle and one of the bird cards that the active player has shows the same colour – very good, the bird  card can be placed
     Rolls a colour: The colour that is rolled is not a “free colour point” or the active player doesn’t have a bird card that shows the colour – too bad, it’s the next player’s turn
     Rolls a “Lame Duck”: The active player draws a “penalty card”
     Rolls a joker: The active player can place an arbitrary card on a free and matching colour point


The player who is first to place all of his bird cards wins the game.

A letter of the alphabet serves as a travel route for the ABC-mobile, in addition, there is a timetable on the letter card, which indicates in which order the stations must be completed. The letters have in principle no stations in the rounds, with the O the two stations are placed at the top, so that one accommodates them at all. On this basis, there are several game variants for one or more children, you can also lay and travel whole words. Whoever reaches the end of his timetable first and has been to all the stations on his letter card wins.

—user summary

A game designed to help children read emotions of people especially during the Covid pandemic where faces are covered by masks.
Made by a childcare worker and designed for use in schools or other educational institutions. Comes with an app and other downloadable games that could be used with that cards set.

The game is more about learning and getting people interested into this topic. 
However, the game flow and win condition are as follows:
You have the card pile in your hand and have to allocate the top card to one of the five emotions. Look at the back of the card to check if you were right. If you were right, keep the card and pass on the pile to the next player. If you were wrong put the card underneath the pile and pass it on. If the pile rans out of cards, the game ends. The player with the most cards win the game.

—user summary

Ein Spieler hat alle Karten, nimmt die oberste und rät, welche Emotion es ist. Liegt man richtig, darf man die Karte behalten und gibt die restlichen Karten weiter! Liegt man falsch, legt man sie unter den Stapel und gibt ihn weiter! Immer der Reihe nach! Wenn der Stapel durch ist, schaut man, wer am meisten Karten besitzt. Derjenige hat gewonnen!

—description from the designer (German)

This soccer game is played on a small field with 11 Nails on each side (representing soccer players) but which actually act as obstacles, a small steel ball and two plastic ice cream spoons to kick the steel ball. The players take turns trying to put the ball in the opponent's goal.
The player to score the most goals in an agreed time, wins the game.

—user summary

Road Trip is an 18 card solo game about a journey across the country. Find the most efficient route for your travels to make it the best road trip by arranging your 9 stops in geographical order (stop number) from left to right using Actions before your deck runs out.

Shuffle all 18 postcards together and set the Route by laying out a line of 9 face up going across the playing area. Set the remainder as the draw deck. Start your adventure by drawing three cards from the deck. Using the actions on the backs, play a card and adjust the Route accordingly. Then draw a new card to bring your hand back to three cards. Continue playing until you have rearranged the Route in order (win), or run out of cards in the deck (lose).

—description from the publisher

Join forces to get the Delorean to 88MPH and go back to the future! Clear all the Paradoxes by using Flux Energy. The problem is, all players are playing from the future and cannot communicate, you can only send signals!

Players need to work together to clear the Paradoxes by laying Flux Energy cards with different values to fulfill each Paradox objective, clearing it from the time continuum.

Each Paradox has a unique problem that must be fixed. Decode the paradox card and find out how to solve them. Once the requirements of the Paradox are met the Delorean is able to move to that space.

You must lay a card on your turn. You can play a card even if it does not help to fix a Paradox or if you cannot go or choose not to go you can reveal the next Paradox in the line. However this causes another Paradox to appear in the future!

Lifelong rivals KITT and KARR go head-to-head in a destructive battle for victory. Drain your opponent’s energy by racing around the map and performing stunts to either attack or defend.

Players choose a Drive card from their hand to
play face down. When flipped over, whoever has the fastest speed goes first. If the colour button matches your previous card you can choose to activate a stunt.

Stunts can be used to attack your opponent, defend an attack or move past or through roadblocks. To perform stunts, players have to perform trick-shots with their car discs.

"Baltic Empires" is an approachable 2-5 player strategic level wargame about conflicts between the states of the Baltic region during the early modern era, a transformative period of religious conflict, large scale warfare, and constant struggles for power. Players will have to develop their economy, strengthen their administration, secure trade hubs, and finally build armies to become the dominant power of the Baltics. Denmark-Norway, Sweden, Russia, Poland-Lithuania, and Prussia will fight for hegemony, using variable victory conditions that reflect their respective historical objectives. Gameplay involves collecting resources, building new infrastructure and units, recruiting historical figures to your court, and finally going to war to expand your empire and fulfil your national ambition.

Highlights:

     Five asymmetric factions with unique abilities and objectives
     A highly thematic deck of historical Dramatis Personae to constitute your royal court
     A simple yet deep economic system that forces players to make tough decisions regarding their finances and wage war for key resources
     A streamlined battle system based on custom dice per unit type
     Variable player counts, from 2 to 5 players, and variable game lengths, with scenarios ranging from a tight duel to a diplomatic heavy conflict with alliances and betrayals


—description from the publisher

A speed/dexterity game that is about finding creatures that do NOT match.

Starting with all the cards face-down, players quickly flip over a card, which they may put into one hand as the first card in their stack. (You may flip another card if you wish.)

Everyone rushes to flip cards and find totally different creature - each card in your stack must be TOTALLY DIFFERENT to the one before - a different number of eyes, mouths, arms/wings/tentacles, and legs.

You may grab turnips - totally different to any creature! But if you have more than 5, you lose.

The game ends when everyone has grabbed as many cards as they can.

Pass your cards left to be checked. If you had 2 cards in a row that are similar, or more than 5 turnips, you lose.

Otherwise, the person with the most cards wins.


Grabbell reimplementation suggested by David Brain.

Turnip idea heavily inspired by Andrew Beardsley.

—description from the designer

This Mega Box includes the original The Quacks of Quedlinburg, The Herb Witches expansion and The Alchemists expansion, all in one box!

In The Quacks of Quedlinburg, players are charlatans — or quack doctors — each making their own secret brew by adding ingredients one at a time. Take care with what you add, though, for a pinch too much of this or that will spoil the whole mixture!

Each player has their own bag of ingredient chips. During each round, they simultaneously draw chips and add them to their pot. The higher the face value of the drawn chip, the further it is placed in the swirling pattern, increasing how much your potion is worth. Push your luck as far as you can, but if you add too many cherry bombs, your pot explodes!

At the end of each round, players gain victory points and coins to spend on new ingredients to add to their bags, depending on the strength of the ingredients in their pots. But players with exploded pots must choose points or coins — not both! The player with the most victory points at the end of nine rounds wins the game.

Included in this box are:


     Quacks: the base game
     The Quacks of Quedlinburg: The Herb Witches: the first expansion, adding Witches that grant powers once per game as well as more ingredient books.
     The Quacks of Quedlinburg: The Alchemists: the second expansion introduces nightmares, obsession, hysteria and a new laboratory player board.

Age of Comics: The Golden Years Age of Comics: The Golden Years is a worker placement management game in which players will run a publishing company during the golden age of comics (1938-54).

In each round the players, in turn, must position 4 meeples (workers called editors). They can choose 4 out of 6 spaces, called publishing tasks. There are 6 publishing tasks in total that can be performed in any order and lead to 6 specific player actions: hire, develop, ideas, print, sales, and royalties. When a player prints a comic book she must pay using monetary resources ($) + 2 identical token ideas and display, on the table, the comic book cover and, underneath, show both a writer and an artist card. The comics’ value (needed for collecting orders on the map) will be the sum of the value of its creatives (artist + writer). Each creative card has a value ranging from 1 to 3.

The game lasts 5 rounds. The objective of the game is to accumulate the highest number of fans, make money by publishing comics and create the best portfolio of comic books. Throughout the game, a fan chart will track the number of fans accumulated by the comics and will award victory points based on the players’ ranking at the end of every round. In the last round, the number of fans is converted into victory points.

The winner is the player who scores the most victory points (VP from now on, represented by a star icon) at the end of five rounds. VP are awarded both during and at the end of the game.

Oh oh, the crocodile's missing a sock! Who is the fastest and finds his matching sock so that Kroko has a complete pair again? The Crocs' Socks! game is an active board game for children and parents. You play it with one to four players. The game consists of cards with coloured socks, cards with a crocodile with only one sock on and four ploppers. One of the participants turns over a card and then everyone tries to catch the missing sock with the plopper as quickly as possible. But watch out! Does Kroko need a left or right sock?

—description from the publisher

Motley Dice is an intriguing puzzle where you roll the dice to generate a unique challenge for every game. Then you must try to place as many dice as you can into the grid, following certain placement restrictions. Challenge yourself, or try one of four different play modes to cooperate or compete with your friends.

To pack some extra punch, this mint tin comes with rules for four other dice games you can play with the 25 dice included. That's 5 games in your pocket!

—description from the designer

Dreams of Empire is a competitive Deck-Building Area-Control game with Hidden Actions. Play as one of 6 Trusted Advisors to the Emperor as you try to sway the imperial council in your favor. However, the Empire is old and weak with new rumor's of revolt brought before the council each day. Without swift action the Empire will shatter. Prove to be the most Influential Advisor and the council will crown you the next Emperor! Can you make your Dreams of Empire come true?

—description from the designer

White box with title and description "Across Europe by Game" in four languages.

The game wants to help open access to the future of Europe in a playful way. It wants to stimulate conversation and discussion, arouse curiosity, and the desire to deal more intensively with the EC member states. If the game succeeds in providing a little general education and understanding for the other EC member states and their inhabitants, then it has fulfilled its main purpose. As a supplement and to loosen up, some information about the global importance of B-Braun Melsungen AG is offered.

Contents: Game board, spinning top, dice, four game figures, 28 question cards with 254 questions and answers.

Redcoats and Rebels-Élan for the American War of Independence is a collaborative work based on the recently released Élan Deluxe rules for 10-25 mm miniatures by Phillip Jones with special contributions from Messrs Mark Hume (AWI specific rules and army lists), Chris Johnson (more army lists) and Greg MacPherson (campaign rules).

Presented in a style similar to Élan Deluxe, (which was recently downloaded for the 10,000th time!), Redcoats and Rebels is well indexed and written in a straightforward clause style.

At nearly 100 pages including play charts, the zipped PDF file also has internal bookmarks for ease of navigation and includes campaign and optional rules, numerous specific unit and general ratings, battle scenarios and orders of battles for several actions in the AWI.

The game is scaled for 1:25, but can be used at the 1:10 to 1:50 ratio and uses any basing system.

The rules sequence features both simultaneous and alternate actions, resulting in an intuitive and balanced game that captures the feel of the period. Individual units represented are the battalion and regiment and players can do sub-unit actions such as company and squadron actions.

The complexity of the game is moderate, and would appeal to a player who enjoys small unit tactics and a wide latitude of unit options (within historical parameters) on the table.

—description from the publisher

In Salvar Doñana, several environmental problems have emerged simultaneously in the Doñana National Park. The players are expert naturalists whose mission is to discover a solution for each of the four environmental problems before they get out of hand.

On each turn, the active player can use up to four actions to travel from one point to another, mitigate environmental problems, discover a solution, or build control centers. A deck of cards will provide players with these abilities, but they will have to be careful with the catastrophe cards, which will accelerate and intensify environmental problems. A second deck of cards will control the inevitable expansion of environmental problems within the National Park.

Assuming a unique role within the team, players must plan their strategy to combine the strengths of their specialties to conquer the solution to environmental problems. But if one or more of those problems extends beyond the point of no return or if too much time passes, all players will lose. If they find a solution to the four environmental problems in time, the players will win.

—description from the designer

Each player receives a ball, which he places to his launching field. All players shoot their ball at the same time if possible. The balls roll into holes that score different points (between 5 and 50). The player who has scored the most points after 4 rounds wins the game.

—user summary

The Russian Front witnessed the biggest tank battles in history.  But for the crews of those vehicles, within each moment, each split second, there was only ever one target in their sights, or the one muzzle that remained unaccounted for. Commander, loader, driver…they served in a cramped world, where the events of four bloody years became nothing but an endless succession of fights for a bridge, a village, or a way out. This is Panzerkampf.

Panzerkampf pitches you into the fight via a short set of rules that have colour and detail where it matters.  Your ace crew, veterans of many such engagements, may conquer all, live to fight another day, or be killed outright by that next unseen muzzle flash. Protection, hitting power, speed, and crew experience are fundamental to the game.  But no one survives without luck, representative of which are a number of random events that can help sway the balance one way or another.  Engines stall; turrets jam; and from out of the sky come Stukas and Sturmoviks.  Their cannon are deadly, but can they always tell friend from foe?

You fight on any flat surface, manoeuvring your force of realistic miniatures and making use of the battlefield terrain supplied with the package.
To get you started, the basic set of Panzerkampf offers 3 T34/41 tank models and 3 Panzer IVf1 models, as well as a supply of scenery.

—description from the publisher

This is a never-released version of Black Rose Wars created by Ludus Magnus Studios. It is for 2 players and follows the basic rules of the original Black Rose Wars game with minor adjustments. It is a cut-out game contained within the Fourth edition of the LMS magazine called Ashes. It contains a folded board with a smaller Lodge that has 2 mage sheets printed near the edges. It comes with 1 new school of magic 'Agony' and 3 forgotten spells.  There are no events or quest cards, instead those are printed on the game board and events are followed over the 3 turns of the game. The players control 2 new mages and can summon a new evocation called a succubus to inflict damage to others and pain upon themselves. This is a great way to introduce new players to the world of Black Rose Wars. Games are estimated at 30-60 minutes.

Welcome to Dreadful Meadows - a land of tricks and treats, where kooky Confectioners compete to be this season's sweetest supplier!

You play a Confectioner, sowing and growing sinister seeds to create the most bountiful candy crops, through crafty candy patch placement. As rounds progress, cultivating your candy crops allows for exciting expansion and experimentation! Conjure up a crew of magic Sugar Sprites who can lend a hand with their abnormal abilities. As you prosper, summon your horrid Harvesters to intensify turnover, or utilize your Candy to discover new Concoctions.

Each game is unique through your choice of Confectioner and the strategies you utilize. Actions and patch varieties are limited, so your success in the meadow will rely on calculated decisions in the expansion of your meadow, the concoctions you create, and how you utilize your Sugar Sprites and Harvesters.

Will your Dreadful Meadow be an abomination, or this season's sweetest sensation?

—description from the publisher

Deep within the darkness of Ulgu, Realm of Shadows, lies an impossible maze sequestered far beneath the sea. Two warbands brave the twisting shadow-magics of this ancient place, one spurred by divine decree and the other by selfish rapacity. Success may mean escape and survival, but few return from Harrowdeep – the nightmare abyss where light itself withers and dies.

Enter the ultimate competitive miniatures game with the Warhammer Underworlds: Harrowdeep Core Set. Inside, you'll find everything you need to start gaming below the waves of the Shadowsea, with miniatures, dice, cards, and more. Harrowdeep marks the beginning of season five of Warhammer Underworlds – a fast-paced, deck-based skirmish game set in the Mortal Realms. You can play right out of the box using the pre-built decks for the Rivals format – which is new to this season – or you can hone your deck using cards from the Warhammer Underworlds card pool for a strategic challenge.

—description from publisher

NOTE: The card back graphics in this set do not match those of all the previous games released in the Warhammer: Underworld series. You will not be able to mix and match cards from other previous sets with this one to deck build a unique team.

The cast of Fantasy Strike has acquired magical gems which give power, but at what price? Those who hold too many gems are cursed forever. What’s worse, the ultimate gem to rule them all has been forged into a single, mighty scepter. Whoever holds it wields even more power at an even greater price.

In Puzzle Strike 2, players build their deck as they play, giving them the tools to arrange and manipulate their set of colored gems. These gems can be “crashed” (destroyed) in order to build up power for four different super moves as well as to flood other players with more gems. As this process unfolds, gems will fly back and forth between players as they desperately try to remain under the threshold of corruption. Holding the scepter “helps,” but can also doom the greedy.

—description from the publisher

In Rainforest City, players repopulate the Singaporean natural landscape by piecing together rainforests, mangroves and ocean terrain with native plants and animals to restore food chains.

Learn about biodiversity, ecosystems and the importance of conservation in this interactive strategy game designed for both families and board game enthusiasts alike!

With competitive, co-operative and solo modes of different difficulties, Rainforest City is a game that challenges as well as educates.

—description from the publisher

Based on the famous Iranian Animated TV series, Shekarestan Bazaar is a worker placement and pick up and delivery board game set in the crowded bazaar of Shekarestan Land.

Players move from one spot to another, trying to buy goods with minimum price and sell in one of the grand bazaars with the highest possible price to win the King's favor for the best merchant of the town.

Based on the famous Iranian Animated TV series, Shekarestan Bazazi is a game set in a bazazi (tailoring) shop in Shekarestan Land. 
Players try to claim the customers and find a suitable fabric to gain coins and be the best tailor in town.

Mountain Rangers is a standalone mini sequel of Forest Guardians, where players continue their mission to protect the forest and wildlife.

Throughout the game, players work on reforestation and animal rescue, while protecting mountains from wildfires and poachers. - description from game box.

Besides planting trees, players gain points when placing the wildlife in their proper habitats; also, putting out fire will produce victory points. The game ends once a player has planted all the forest meeples on their character boards.

Football combo story is a football-themed game that can be played alone or with two players in confrontation.

A match takes place over 2 halves during which you will have to resolve 8 phases of the game: 4 offensives and 4 defenses.
It's up to you to manage your workforce well to meet the objectives to defend or score goals.

Master Strikes is a high skill-cap 15th century German longsword card game where players honor-duel to the first cut. The game utilizing authentic fighting stances, swing types from each stance, and counter moves which force players to change stances in order to react.

Master Strikes relies on deduction and memory, as well as chess-like strategy to outwit your foe. The game is easy to learn and hard to master, with several balanced methods to find an advantage.

BookWorms is a simple word search game where players, acting as worms, find letters in adjacent books to form words.

PLAY IN ROUNDS

Play at least two rounds. Each round consists of setup and game play until the draw piles are depleted.

GAME PLAY

On each turn, the current player …

     Examines letters adjacent to and in a path of letters from their location.
     Calls out a word using any nearby letters and optionally one letter from a draw pile.
     Moves their bookworm to the location of the last letter used.
     Collects all the book tiles used. 
     Places the tiles collected upside down in front of them.
     Takes a random tile from the draw pile and places it face up on any empty board space.
     Moves the mole.


The mole is used to steal a random book from an adjacent bookworm.

Making a Move

     Move your bookworm onto a location where the first letter will be used to form your word. The location must be adjacent to, or within a continuous “tunnel” of five empty spaces from your worm’s current position. However, you cannot move next to, or pass next to the mole.
     The word will be a combination of adjacent letters in sequential order and optionally a letter or bigram from any draw pile.
     Call out the word for others to verify.
     Pick up the tiles used and them place in front of you upside down.
     Move the worm to the location of the last letter used.


TIP: Try to use letters with the highest values.

Moving the Mole
The current player moles the mole at the end of their turn. The mole is moved onto a book tile whose letter matches the first letter of the word just made.
If the mole is moved next to a worm, that player loses one of their collected letter tiles at random.  The current player selects one of the that player’s tiles and places it face up on a random board location.

ENDING THE ROUND
When all players agree that no more words can be formed, the game is over. 
Each player tallies their collected books’ points and records them on a score sheet. Repeat the setup and play at least one more round.
Repeat the setup and play at least two rounds.

ENDING THE GAME
At the end of the last round, the winner will have the most points. In case of a tie, the youngest player wins.

—description from the publisher

The ideal family fun for everyone!
Playable in many variations with or without rotating wheel.
First one to get all pieces into the target area wins.

—description from the publisher (translated)

Kreisverkehr is a variant of Malefiz. In this variant, a part of the board can rotate, and it is rotated whenever a player rolls multiple sixes in a row.

—user summary

The players collect clues on clue squares to exchange them for 4 star cards. In addition, the 3 girls' pieces must be moved to the target square before the boys' piece. The figures are moved by a dice roll.
The collected clues are immediately deposited in a cloth bag. When a player thinks they can acquire one of the 4 face-up star cards, clue cards are drawn from the cloth bag. Clue cards that do not match are lost.

—user summary

Pandemonium Estate is an Otherworldly, Thematic Adventure board game for 2-5 players. Pandemonium Estate takes place in an interdimensional mansion that exists between world and time. The heart of the mansion, the Verge Portal, consumes objects and people from the many worlds it visits, trapping them in the mansion against their will.

Players can choose to play one of three full-length, replayable thematic Storyline modes as one of eight playable characters with their own unique Traits. Regardless of the chosen Storyline, players must complete various tasks in order to gain enough Essence (Victory Points) to return to their home world.

—description from the designer

Do you have what it takes to hit the big time? Can you take your band from performing in your parents’ basement to the largest stages around the world?
  Draft your lead singer, musicians, production and backstage staff. Arrange them in the most harmonious ways to unlock more fans, money and opportunities. Plan your schedule, prioritize your assets and select your travel routes as you grow.
  Chain your rewards into such an amazing show that you will leave your competitors behind. But as every superstar knows...watch out for those scandals.

Draft & Write Records is a draft and write game for 1-6 players, aged 10+ taking 45 minutes.

—description from the publisher

Your transit company has been hired to construct subway tunnels and stops, connecting the districts of the city. Will your project stay on track, or will it go off the rails?

Terminus is a resource management and subway development game for 1 - 5 players, featuring a rondel and variable marketplace.

During the game, players will circle the city taking actions to:

-Purchase developments, upgrades, and materials
-Lobby Projects and Agendas
-And build stops and rails for their subway lines

While the economy shifts and resources become more scarce, players must try to outwit each other and earn prestige by fulfilling public project objectives and their own private agendas.

The player who's earned the most prestige wins the game!

—description from the publisher

The realm of Rolaria has been plunged into chaos by a war among Deities. The divine forces at play have created ruptures between dimensions & various locations within the realm. These portals hold the key to triumph over the other regions battling for control of Rolaria. As a player, you will assume the role of a Deity, commanding an army of Allies, strategically positioning them to secure access to these portals while simultaneously directing your Champions in the heat of battle. Prepare to unleash your divine power and lead your armies to glory in this epic fantasy-themed card game.

—description from the publisher

Recreate the Air War over the European theater of World War II as part of the epic clash between the Allies and Germans in some of the most historic battles of World War II, during the years 1941-1945.
 Eagles Over Europe is a historical boardgame where players take the roles of US Army Airforce and the RAF (including the Polish pilots, of course!) to participate in WWII's most famous battles, including Omaha Beach, Pegasus Bridge, Operation Cobra, and the Ardennes (Battle of the Bulge).  You'll also deal with the bombing campaign, as Mustangs and Thunderbolts try to protect the B-17s from hordes of Luftwaffe fighters. 
Eagles Over Europe includes over 15 battle scenarios, all fought out on a huge, 140 cm x 100 cm game board (55" x 39"). Each scenario recreates the historical objectives of the two sides, and includes special events that impacted the battle's outcome.
Eagles Over Europe is designed to be easy-entry, but the game mechanics require strategic card play and finding skillful combinations between the dice, the symbols on the cards, and pilot abilities. In addition to the huge gameboard, Eagles over Europe includes detailed airplane miniatures, beautifully illustrated Combat cards, Scenario, Event and Pilot cards. Special Terrain tiles and Custom dice complete the "wow" people will feel when they open the box. 
Those familiar with the "303 Squadron" game will recognize the core game mechanics but enjoy additions like Flak, RADAR, ground attack, and many more. But you don't have to have 303 Squadron to play Eagles Over Europe-- it is a totally free-standing game. 
Eagles Over Europe is designed as a co-operative game for 1 - 4 players. The average game length is between 60 and 90 minutes. Each scenario includes innovative and clever mechanics, dynamic gameplay, and startling surprises...all "normal" for Eagles Over Europe!

Players are given chips and a lottery ticket on which they mark 6 numbers (out of 44). From the starting field, they travel through the American states and are allowed to move one step at a time when one of their 6 numbers is drawn. Events (chip win, chip loss) are triggered on some of the spaces reached. If all 6 numbers were drawn by a player, that player is allowed to go 6 more steps. Then all players have to buy a new lottery ticket and the procedure starts again. The first player to reach the target field with at least 20 chips wins the game.

—user summary

The players move along a route by rolling the dice and have to solve tasks on event fields and mostly drink a beer. The first player to reach field 30 alive is the winner.

—user summary

One minute is not the world, right? Do you think so even if you have even less time to memorize every detail of an image? Memorace board game amusingly develops not only memory but also general knowledge and literacy. Learning becomes a captivating experience with its tasteful illustrations. How good is your memory?

Take the initial steps towards learning the ABCs. Your child can learn the letters by playing and his vocabulary also expands.

You can play Memorace alone or with more people.

     Draw a card and put it in front of you!
     Turn the clock over and try to memorize as many details as possible before the sand drips off - it’s about 10 seconds.
     Throw the dice!
     If you rolled 1, you must answer the thought-provoking puzzle on the front panel. Look at the picture and calculate or deduce correctly!
     If you did not roll 1, turn the card over and answer the question on the back next to the rolled number. These will put your memory to the test, but if you watch well, you will know the answer for sure!


There’s no reason to get frustrated even if you didn’t know the answer, turn the card over and find the solution! However, if you answered correctly, you can keep the card - congratulations, you already have a point!
Who will collect the most cards? Can you break your own record?

It is June 1941.  The Third Reich embarks upon the greatest military campaign of all time.  The Wehrmacht attacks across an 1800 mile front, 3.8 million men, 3350 tanks, 3000 aircraft, and 23,000 artillery pieces.
 Now, as a tactical commander in the most significant campaign of the 20th century, it is up to you to win your battles, and shape the world, before it's too late!
 (This is a Combat Boots game.  Each unit represents a squad, individual gun, tank, or aircraft.  Each space is 50 meters across, and each turn is approximately 5 minutes long.  Best played face-to-face, but the game includes provisions for solitaire play)

Actual character voices and realistic sound effects bring Beauty and the Beast to life as you make your move in the 3-D palace ballroom and courtyard.

An enchantress has turned the Prince into a Beast, and all his servants into Enchanted Objects. Use your memory to help bell break the spell-and make them all human again. The player that reveals the Prince wins the game.

Players press the center button on the Sound Randomizer board, following the instructions given.  The aim of the game is to collect 5 Enchanted Objects chips. which are needed to turn the Beast Human.  Players have 5 chances to turn the beast human.  The player who turns over the correct magic rose square, wins the game.

Irukandji is the first game in the SNACKBOX Mini Game Series.

You have swum a long way out, and it is now time to head home. Race back to the beach without coming across one of the most venomous jellyfish in the world: the Irukandji.

Irukandji is a game of tile laying and tile playing. Swim well, use the conditions, and watch out for the Irukandji.

Be the first player to get to +2 (points) on the scorecard, by scoring each swim to The Beach.

Take turns moving from tile to tile, dealing with the ocean conditions as you go while trying to avoid the hidden dangers. Aim to get back to The Beach first, and collect the Beach Ball token, if you can.

—description form the publisher

Chimichangas and Tacos is the third game in the SNACKBOX Mini Game Series. So let's not burrito round the bush. You think this is nacho game? Let's taco bout it.

This game is about making tasty Tacos, Taquitos, Nachos, Quesidillas, Enchiladas, Burritos, and of course...Chimichangas!

Grab chips to reveal your ingredients, then fill, wrap, fry, and top your way to the most delicious meals on the menu.

Complete the tastiest meals and score the highest number of points (and Tacos), over several rounds.

Pick ‘chips’ from a pile and stack the ingredients to make meals (using the Recipes). Make sure you complete your meals, as it will cost you. Add some tasty condiments if you want to enhance the flavor!

—description from the publisher

Yuru Camp x Cat & Chocolate is an anime-based version of storytelling game Cat & Chocolate. Based on the Yuru Camp theme, players will use items to solve problems while camping. The team that solves more problems wins.
